data.title: Cross-compile for ARM fails from x64
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `scripts/npm.sh install --arch=arm` from x64 machine
2. `gulp vscode-linux-arm-build-deb`
3. install deb on ARM machine
4. `code --verbose`
```
[27655:0211/221027:INFO:CONSOLE(4)] "Loading "gc-signals" failed", source: file:///usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js (4)
[27655:0211/221027:INFO:CONSOLE(4)] "Detail: ", source: file:///usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js (4)
[27655:0211/221027:INFO:CONSOLE(4)] "Error: /usr/share/code/resources/app/node_modules/gc-signals/build/Release/gcsignals.node: wrong ELF class: ELFCLASS64
    at Error (native)
    at process.module.(anonymous function) [as dlopen] (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:178:20)
    at Object.Module._extensions..node (module.js:583:18)
    at Object.module.(anonymous function) [as .node] (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:178:20)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/code/resources/app/node_modules/gc-signals/src/index.js:8:18)", source: file:///usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js (4)
[27655:0211/221027:INFO:CONSOLE(4)] "Here are the modules that depend on it:", source: file:///usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js (4)
[27655:0211/221027:INFO:CONSOLE(4)] "vs/workbench/api/node/mainThreadHeapService", source: file:///usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/loader.js (4)
```
Looks like `gc-signals` is ignoring the `--arch` flag and getting built for x64.

data.title: How can an extension expand configuration variables?
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
 OS Version:  Windows 10 AU (1607)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Start with a debug extension sample like mock-debug
2.  In scripting environments, you often want to launch the current, active file. So you create a launch config with `"program":` set to `"${file}"`. 
3. However, your workspace has other file types (.md, .json, .yml, etc) which aren't script files and can't be debugged.  So you'd like to test the extension of the file to be debugged so put up a vscode error message stating that launch.json can't be debugged.  However, all I'm seeing is `"${file}"`.  How do I resolve this to the actual file path?  I see there is an IConfigurationResolverService but I can't figure out how to access it.  It doesn't appear to be available for consumption by an extension.

data.title: "File to read not found or unreadable" using node-sass when saving on VSCode
data.body:
Cross posting with sass/node-sass/issues/1894

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a folder called `styles` and place a `styles.scss` inside that folder
2. Create a node-sass 4.5.0 watch command as such: `node-sass styles/styles.scss --output-style compressed --watch --linefeed lf --source-map true --output styles`
3. There's a random chance that after editing and saving the styles.scss file, the node-sass task will fail with (fails around 30% of the time, sometimes 4-5 times in a row)

```
=> changed: G:\www\styles\styles.scss
{
  "status": 3,
  "message": "File to read not found or unreadable: G:/www/styles/styles.scss",
  "formatted": "Internal Error: File to read not found or unreadable: G:/www/styles/styles.scss\n"
}
=> changed: G:\www\styles\styles.scss
Rendering Complete, saving .css file...
Wrote CSS to G:\www\styles\styles.css
Wrote Source Map to G:\www\styles\styles.css.map
```

trying to see whose fault is it

data.title: [html] prevent that embedded grammars can corrupt syntax highlighting of rest of document

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently, when writing embedded language, a lot of the times the embedded grammar can cause disruption to the rest of DOCUMENT:

This is html grammar.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/22858475/9430d0b4-f08c-11e6-8386-e949dcccfb20.png)

Imagine editing css in a `<style>` at the `<head>` of a long html file. The rest of document will be constantly re-tokenized and (wrongly) syntax highlighted. This doesn't look good UX-wise and will probably have some perf impact.

For the following grammar and setting:

```yaml
- name: source.css.embedded.html
   begin: <style>
   end: </style>
   patterns:
   - include: source.css
```

```json
"embeddedLanguages": {
  "source.css": "css"
}
```

I hope VSCode can only apply CSS grammar to the section between `<style>` and `</style>`, so when I'm typing out my incomplete CSS VSCode would just re-tokenize and highlight until `</style>`, but not rest of the document.

/cc @alexandrudima 

Also would like to hear @aeschli's opinion, as you are writing the html grammar.

data.title: Trying to insert a snippet using multiple cursors only inserts at first created cursor
data.body:
If I create 3 cursors (for example using alt+click) and then try to insert a snippet at those locations, the snippet will only be inserted at the first cursor location.

In this example, I first created the bottom cursor, then the middle one, then the top one:

![snippet in multiple cursors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/532708/22857608/f78c2790-f09f-11e6-884d-ac7e5fd0a950.gif)

Expected behavior would be to insert it at all three cursors. Then, the snippet's tab stops should happen for all of them as expected (i.e. press tab once and it moves to the next tab stop on all of them). Sublime implements the expected behavior.

data.title: Feature Request: Optional setting to automatically update extensions
data.body:
VSCode might benefit from automatically applying updates for extensions, rather than requiring the user to kick off extension updates. I often see the notification pop up on the extensions icon, asking me to update several extensions, and kind of wish that it was just a notification to restart, because the updates had already been applied in the background.

Any thoughts? Pros / cons?

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: autocomplete shouldn't suggest on empty word
data.body:
Autocomplete suggestions should be completely reset/removed if the current word is removed/cleared
Something about the way I format as I code, I often hit a scenario.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.9.0-insider (882244ea24cb0b89a9a0c6c649c8f857fb0bc408, 2017-01-23T07:03:07.900Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-62-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|lualinter|dcr30|1.0.3|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|Lua|keyring|0.0.9|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.7.0|
|debug|webfreak|0.17.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:
1. begin typing a word (autocompletion suggestions begin to display)
2. backspace the word out fully bringing the cursor back to where the word started
3. press enter (or tab, depending on what your 'accept suggestion' is set to)

Expected behavior
When you removed the word back to the first cursor position, the suggestions should be unloaded
You should get a literal newline (or tab)

Actual behavior
The suggestion box remained and the editor autocompletes

data.title: VS Code freezes when removing 'node_modules' folder from external terminal, forcing to close

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-stylesheet-formatter|dbalage|0.2.0|
|vscode-instant-markdown|dbankier|1.0.0|
|vscode-material2-snippets|deerawan|1.0.1|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.3.9|
|Angular2|johnpapa|1.0.2|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.3|
|autoimport|steoates|1.2.2|
|bootstrap-3-snippets|wcwhitehead|0.0.9|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a NPM project (with a `node_modules` folder) from root folder 
2. remove the entire  `node_modules` folder  with (`rm -rf node_modules` or `rmdir /s /q node_modules`)

From there, the only working option  is to choose `Close` VS Code, when the "not responding" window pops up.

Note that  disabling "file watching" on `node_modules` in settings (as suggested by #12042) DOES work (the application no longer hangs on deletion, but we loose automatic assistance of newly installed packages).
```
"files.watcherExclude": {
    "**/.git/objects/**": true,
    "**/node_modules/**": true
}
```

But is there not a better solution? 

Thanks in advance

data.title: Output Channel API Incomplete for Language Servers
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows

I have a language server extension and I'd like to write logs.

My understanding is this:
1. The server recieves an IConnection object which has a console and a window. The window can show info/warning/error messages and the console can log to the chrome dev console, but neither offer access to output channels
2. The server can use a "normal" console.log (not the console from the IConnection object) which will manifest in the VS Code UI as an output channel with the name that the server was initialized with. However, there is no handle to the output channel available in the language server so it cannot be shown, for example when an error is logged.
3. The client can create an output channel and the server can route all logs to it as `requests`. Then all events that would need to open/close the channel also need to be manually routed to the client through `requests` or included as parameters in the log request. This seems like an unnecessary amount of boilerplate and indirection just to do basic logging.

Since it appears that an output channel is being created for the language server anyway as described in item 2, it should be exposed as part of the API and/or additional API functions should be added to support output channels in language servers

data.title: Output channels with same name confuse VS Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a language client/server extension
2. Initialize the Language Client with the name "repro". (`let languageClient = new LanguageClient('repro', serverOptions, clientOptions);` )
3. In the client, create an output channel with the name "repro" (`let outputChannel = vscode.window.createOutputChannel('repro');`)
4. In the client, write something to the output channel (i.e. 'client side')
5. In the server, perform a console.log statement (i.e. 'server side')

Observe in the output pane there are now two channels named 'repro'. Selecting each of them will show the contents of whichever output channel was written to last.
